user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleLoad_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleLoad_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *translated_path)
{
    int32                             status = OS_ERROR;
    int                               dl_mode;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;
    OS_module_internal_record_t *     module;

    impl   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);
    module = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_module_table, *token);

    /*
     * RTLD_NOW should instruct dlopen() to resolve all the symbols in the
     * module immediately, as opposed to waiting until they are used.
     * The latter (lazy mode) is non-deterministic - a resolution error on
     * a rarely-used symbol could cause a random failure far in the future.
     */
    dl_mode = RTLD_NOW;

    if ((module->flags & OS_MODULE_FLAG_LOCAL_SYMBOLS) != 0)
    {
        /*
         * Do not add the symbols in this module to the global symbol table.
         * This mode helps prevent any unanticipated references into this
         * module, which can in turn prevent unloading via dlclose().
         */
        dl_mode |= RTLD_LOCAL;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Default mode - add symbols to the global symbol table, so they
         * will be available to resolve symbols in future module loads.
         * However, any such references will prevent unloading of this
         * module via dlclose().
         */
        dl_mode |= RTLD_GLOBAL;
    }

    dlerror();
    impl->dl_handle = dlopen(translated_path, dl_mode);
    if (impl->dl_handle != NULL)
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error loading shared library: %s\n", dlerror());
    }

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleLoad_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_module_internal_record_t OS_impl_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
extern OS_module_internal_record_t OS_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    /* cppcheck-suppress unusedStructMember */
    void *dl_handle;
} OS_impl_module_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char             module_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    char             file_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    OS_module_type_t module_type;
    uint32           flags;
    cpuaddr          entry_point;
} OS_module_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_MODULE_FLAG_LOCAL_SYMBOLS 0x01
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I included all code fragments that reference the function parameters or that take the address of a token expression (the macro and the inline helper). Those are the only places in the provided code that could possibly affect the parameter variables themselves (token or translated_path) or depend on how the token expression is passed. Other code fragments do not need investigation for Rule 17.8 because:
- There are no assignments to the parameters token or translated_path anywhere in the function (no statements like token = ... or translated_path = ...). The parameters are declared const, preventing modification of the pointed-to objects via those pointers in this function.
- The remaining statements only compute or modify local variables (dl_mode, status, impl->dl_handle) or test module->flags; these do not modify the parameter variables themselves.
- Calls such as dlerror() and dlopen(...) use translated_path but do not modify the translated_path parameter variable; dlopen takes a const char * and returns a handle assigned to impl->dl_handle (a field of the object pointed to by impl), which is allowed (modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted; only modification of the pointer parameter itself is prohibited).
- Bitwise operations on module->flags and assignments to local dl_mode and status affect local data, not the function parameter variables.
Therefore the only fragments requiring inspection for potential violation of "a function parameter should not be modified" are the ones that reference the parameters or take addresses of token expressions (listed above).
